 I agree. We can still argue whether the 2nd. Amendment recognizes an individual RKBA all we want, but SCOTUS has decided that issue. The legal focus has now turned to what I see are three issues. 
 
 #1: Incorporation. 
 
 Incorporation against the states through the doctrine of selective incorporation was never an issue in Heller-but it will likely become the major issue soon. Nordyke, for example, could provide the test case for the answer if SCOTUS accepted an appeal. In any event the issue of incorporation is vital.
 
 If the RKBA is not incorporated, then the only protection the individual RKBA has against state infringement would be a similar state constitutional guarantee. If a state does not have a RKBA provision, or if that state's supreme court ruled the state provision did not guarantee an individual RKBA, then the state would be free to enact a total ban on possession of any firearm. In other words, in this circumstance your RKBA would exist only at the discretion of your state legislator-regardless of what Heller says. 
 
 #2: The test.
 
 Whenever a law is challenged on the grounds that it unconstitutionally infringes upon an individual right SCOTUS uses a test to evaluate the claim. 
 
 The strongest test is called "strict scrutiny"-and it applies when laws infringing a "fundamental right" are challenged:
 
 Unquestionably we have held that a government practice or statute which restricts "fundamental rights" or which contains "suspect classifications" is to be subjected to "strict scrutiny" and can be justified only if it furthers a compelling government purpose and, even then, only if no less restrictive alternative is available. University of California Regents v. Bakke, 438 U.S. 265, 357 (1978) ["suspect classifications," by the way, refer to things like race-based preferences]
 
 This is the test I believe SCOTUS needs to adopt. In my opinion the other tests (intermediate scrutiny and rational basis) would leave the RKBA at the mercy of irritated lawmakers. The Heller majority evaded this issue entirely. All we know is what tests it rejected. District Of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. ___ 07290, 62-63 (2008)
 
 A. Justice Breyer's offer of a new "only if the judge thinks it's still worth having the right" test is rejected:
 
 JUSTICE BREYER moves on to make a broad jurisprudential point: He criticizes us for declining to establish a level of scrutiny for evaluating Second Amendment restrictions. He proposes, explicitly at least, none of the traditionally expressed levels (strict scrutiny, intermediate scrutiny, rational basis), but rather a judge-empowering "interestbalancing inquiry" that "asks whether the statute burdens a protected interest in a way or to an extent that is out of proportion to the statute's salutary effects upon other important governmental interests." Post, at 10. After an exhaustive discussion of the arguments for and against gun control, JUSTICE BREYER arrives at his interestbalanced answer: because handgun violence is a problem, because the law is limited to an urban area, and because there were somewhat similar restrictions in the founding period (a false proposition that we have already discussed), the interest-balancing inquiry results in the constitutionality of the handgun ban. QED. 
 We know of no other enumerated constitutional right whose core protection has been subjected to a freestanding "interest-balancing" approach. The very enumeration of the right takes out of the hands of government-even the Third Branch of Government-the power to decide on a case-by-case basis whether the right is really worth insisting upon. A constitutional guarantee subject to future judges' assessments of its usefulness is no constitutional guarantee at all. Constitutional rights are enshrined with the scope they were understood to have when the people adopted them, whether or not future legislatures or (yes) even future judges think that scope too broad. We would not apply an "interest-balancing" approach to the prohibition of a peaceful neo-Nazi march through Skokie. See National Socialist Party of America v. Skokie, 432 U. S. 43 (1977) (per curiam). The First Amendment contains the freedom-of-speech guarantee that the people ratified, which included exceptions for obscenity, libel, and disclosure of state secrets, but not for the expression of extremely unpopular and wrong-headed views. The Second Amendment is no different. Like the First, it is the very product of an interest-balancing by the people-which JUSTICE BREYER would now conduct for them anew. And whatever else it leaves to future evaluation, it surely elevates above all other interests the right of law-abiding, responsible citizens to use arms in defense of hearth and home.
 
 B: A rejection of "rational basis"
 
 JUSTICE BREYER correctly notes that this law, like almost all laws, would pass rational-basis scrutiny. Post, at 8. But rational-basis scrutiny is a mode of analysis we have used when evaluating laws under constitutional commands that are themselves prohibitions on irrational laws. See, e.g., Engquist v. Oregon Dept. of Agriculture, 553 U. S. ___, ___ (2008) (slip op., at 9-10). In those cases, "rational basis"is not just the standard of scrutiny, but the very substance of the constitutional guarantee. Obviously, the same test could not be used to evaluate the extent to which a legislature may regulate a specific, enumerated right, be it the freedom of speech, the guarantee against double jeopardy, the right to counsel, or the right to keep and bear arms. See United States v. Carolene Products Co., 304 U. S. 144, 152, n. 4 (1938) ("There may be narrower scope for operation of the presumption of constitutionality [i.e., narrower than that provided by rational-basis review] when legislation appears on its face to be within a specific prohibition of the Constitution, such as those of the first ten amendments. . ."). If all that was required to overcome the right to keep and bear arms was a rational basis, the Second Amendment would be redundant with the separate constitutional prohibitions on irrational laws, and would have no effect.
 
 #3: Fundamental/non-fundamental right status.
 
 This final issue is related to what test we use when reviewing a challenged law. If the right is viewed as "fundamental," then the test used for an invasion of the core right will be "strict scrutiny." Heller did not address the fundamental/non-fundamental issue. The closest the majority came was here-during a discussion of the meaning of the "operative" clause of the 2nd. A:
 
 By the time of the founding, the right to have arms had become fundamental for English subjects. See Malcolm 122-134. Blackstone, whose works, we have said, "constituted the preeminent authority on English law for the founding generation," Alden v. Maine, 527 U.S. 706, 715 (1999), cited the arms provision of the Bill of Rights as one of the fundamental rights of Englishmen. See 1 Blackstone 136, 139-140 (1765). His description of it cannot possibly be thought to tie it to militia or military service. It was, he said, "the natural right of resistance and self-preservation," District Of Columbia v. Heller, 554 U.S. ___ 07290, 20 (2008)
 
 There are a number of opinions, however, which strongly suggest that all rights specifically enumerated in the BoR are deemed "fundamental." These opinions take the trend of assuming the first 8 amendments enshrined fundamental rights, and they go on to say the 9th. A tells us there are other unenumerated rights which are also "fundamental." For example: 
 
 [T]he Ninth Amendment shows a belief of the Constitution's authors that fundamental rights exist that are not expressly enumerated in the first eight amendments and an intent that the list of rights included there not be deemed exhaustive. Palmer v. Thompson, 403 U.S. 217, 237 (1971)
 
 In any event, SCOTUS should in my opinion declare that the 2nd. A is a fundamental right. To do otherwise would open the door for others to attack different specific rights in the BoR as also being non-fundamental.  So when the Second Amendment talks about the security of a free state is it referring to security against slave rebellions?

 
 The short answer is no. Bogus is a biased researcher pushing a flawed product. I read his article when it was first published, and in my opinion it has not improved with age. But it is too easy to just say "Bogus is biased and cannot be believed." Therefore, let me offer some specific criticisms of his work.
 
 The article was Bogus' attempt to validate a collective/state's right theory. I believe this is the first time (at least it was the first time I had seen it before) that anyone suggested Madison had a secretive hidden agenda with the 2nd. Amendment. In a nutshell, Bogus claims the real purpose of the 2nd. Amendment was that of mollifying the southern slaveholding states by giving them a RKBA amendment which merely promised the federal government could not disarm the state militias they needed to keep their slaves in check. When I first read his article I did not find any evidence to support his claim. Upon reading it again I still can find none. In the article Bogus explains his lack of evidence this way:
 
 "The history of the Second Amendment was hidden by design."
 
 According to Bogus, this collective/state's right design was hidden so well that Madison fooled everyone with it, and that it took some 200 years for an associate law professor with an active imagination to first uncover the Amendment's real purpose. The problem I have with Bogus is he ignores the mountain of direct evidence-from both Madison's own pen as well as many, many of his contemporaries-which show they all believed the RKBA was an individual right. (I'll cite several examples later in another post if you want me too). This is called direct evidence, and Bogus does nothing to dispute or refute the mountain of direct written evidence against his theory.
 
 Instead, he selectively takes one word from the amendment ("security") and reads it out of context to support his claim (that "security" really means protection from slave uprising rather than the actual amendment language "security of a free state"-where men live in freedom without fear of a domestic tyrant) . In doing so Bogus chooses, for example, to also ignore the language "the right of the people"-as well he should, for being a law professor he either knows or should know that Madison chose to use this specific language in the 1st, 2nd, and 4th Amendments, and that in each instance it refers to an individual right (1st "the right of the people peaceably to assemble"; 2nd "the right of the people to keep and bear arms"; 4th "The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures")
 
 In my opinion it is a poor argument indeed to suggest that Madison would choose such explicit individual right language as a cloak for his hidden collective/state's right agenda. 
 
 Bogus does correctly tell us of the anti-federalist fear that Congress-having exclusive Article 1 section 8 power to arm and equip the militias-could effectively disarm the militias by simply refusing to arm them. Yet in such a circumstance the states cannot arm their own militias without running afoul of the Article 6 supremacy clause. Bogus fails to clearly explain how his hidden agenda purpose of the 2nd amendment would assist the states were this to happen. Interestingly enough, however, Bogus does cite U.S. v. Miller, which if he read in its entirety he would find tells him (and us) that the militias of the day were primarily armed by men "appear[ing] bearing arms supplied by themselves and in common use at the time." 
 
 What Bogus fails (or refuses) to see in my opinion is that the purpose of the congressional power to arm the militias was to better ensure the standardization of militia arms, while the purpose of the 2nd. Amendment (at least that part dealing with militias) was to ensure the people could remain individually armed and provide a source of emergency arms for service-which the states were forbidden by the Constitution to provide-if needed to confront a tyrant and maintain a "free state." 
 
 In any event, if the purpose of the amendment was to ensure the collective states' "right" to have an armed militia to keep slaves in bondage, then the Amendment could have easily been clearly written to read "the states shall have the power to concurrently arm their militias" (or, the Article 1 section 8 congressional power clause could have been amended to grant the states concurrent power to arm their militias if Congress refused to do so). Madison (a slave owner himself before, during, and after his presidency) could have avoided all this risk of being so misunderstood by writing it this way. And if, as Bogus claims, slavery was so embarrassing then there is equally no need to mention the purpose of continuing slavery at all with this language. 
 
 But Bogus presses on with his theory in his article. He wraps up his theory with an apology for not having any direct evidence to support it:
 
 "The evidence that the Second Amendment was written to assure the South that the federal government would not disarm its militia is, I suggest, considerable. However, the evidence is almost entirely circumstantial.[303] If the thesis is sound, why is no direct evidence to be found supporting it?"
 
 Here Bogus admits he cannot offer a single piece of direct evidence in support of his hidden agenda theory (a speech, a quote from private letters, etc.). But he goes on to tell us it's not his fault. Instead, he speculates that a stenographer's conspiracy may have existed to deny him direct evidence of his theory:
 
 "That is, to the extent that express statements about slave control were made at ratifying conventions in the South or later in the First Congress, stenographers may have considered it both politic and convenient to abbreviate or omit those remarks."
 
 We are, therefore, truly fortunate to be able to rely upon professor Bogus' powers of divination to discover the true meaning of the 2nd. Amendment. And, perhaps knowing that such a mystical ability would be doubted, Bogus seeks to reassure the reader of the strength of circumstantial evidence were his power of divination actually on trial (in footnote 303):
 
 "303. As evidence experts understand, however, circumstantial evidence can be just as strong and compelling as direct evidence and sometimes even more so. See JOHN HENRY WIGMORE, 1a EVIDENCE IN TRIALS AT COMMON LAW § 26, at 961 (rev. by Petter Tillers 1983); see also GRAHAM C. LILLY, AN INTRODUCTION TO THE LAW OF EVIDENCE 49 (3d ed. 1996)."
 
 I am familiar with Wigmore's treatise, which is heavily relied upon in my state. I cite Bogus' claim about the power of circumstantial evidence here because I want to tell you he withholds from the reader the following contradictory and well known statement about this type of evidence:
 
 "When the evidence is wholly circumstantial, as here, all necessary circumstances proved must be consistent with guilt and inconsistent with innocence and exclude every reasonable hypothesis of innocence. The chain of necessary circumstances must be unbroken." Inge v. Commonwealth, 217 Va. 360, 366, 228 S.E.2d 563, ___ (1976) 
 
 That is, what Bogus hides from the reader with his "my circumstantial evidence can be strong" claim is that when, as he does, you rely wholly on circumstantial evidence, then it is only considered strong evidence when there are no facts, direct or otherwise, which contradict the circumstantial evidence's theory. As I said, I can give several quotes from Madison and others referring to the RKBA as an individual right, all of which Bogus simply chooses to ignore. 
 
 In the end, Bogus' research methodology really seems to mirror that of Bellesiles'. This complaint was made about Bellesiles' research, which applies just as equally to Bogus' research: He showed up at a cocktail party and immediately stood up on his toes to peer over the crowded room of direct and contradictory evidence in search of a few circumstantial evidence friends.
 
 In his article Bogus reports from the cocktail party that there was: "a tacit collaboration to leave unsaid what everyone so clearly understood." (the "understanding" being that the amendment is not about individual liberties but only intended to protect a state's right to arm its militia). 
 
 This quote leads me to ask Bogus which conspiracy theory he is really relying upon now. Was it a conspiracy of the founders to leave this secret purpose unsaid between them? Or, as he suggested earlier, did the founders debate the wisdom of this secret purpose between themselves only to have the stenographers later conspire to edit it all out?) Regardless of which unproven conspiracy theory bogus relies upon to support his claim, I cannot resist offering at least one example of someone who either didn't get the message or who managed to avoid the censorship altogether:
 
 "As civil rulers, not having their duty to the people duly before them, may attempt to tyrannize, and as the military forces which must be occasionally raised to defend our country, might pervert their power to the injury of their fellow citizens, the people are confirmed by the article in their right to keep and bear private arms." Tench Coxe, discussing the purpose of the Second Amendment in his "Remarks on the First Part of the Amendments to the Federal Constitution," published under the pseudonym, "A Pennsylvanian" in the Philadelphia Federal Gazette, June 18, 1789 at 2 Col. 1. (Emphasis added)
 
 "It has appeared to me that a few well tempered observations on these propositions might have good effect. . . .It may perhaps be of use in the present turn of the public opinions in New York State . . ." Tench Coxe, 12 Madison Papers, pp. 239-240 (Rutland Ed. 1979) [Letter from Coxe to Madison, June 18, 1789, offering his "Remarks" to help sway public opinion toward ratification of the proposed Bill of Rights during Madison's campaign for their adoption in New York].
 
 "[Your] printed remarks enclosed [with your letter] are already I find in the Gazettes here. . . .[my proposed amendments are] therefore already indebted to the co-operation of your pen." Id. p. 257 (Rutland Ed. 1979) [Letter from Madison to Coxe, June 24, 1789, thanking him for the help with his "Remarks"].
 
 There, that's enough criticism for now of Bogus' bogus theory. In the end, I ask that you go back and read what has been written about the purpose and intent of the 14th. Amendment-and then consider this:
 
 Assuming for a moment that Bogus was correct-that the 2nd Amendment was intended to be only a states'/collective right to keep the sword in the hands of the southern states and allow them to hold the black man in bondage. Didn't the 14th. Amendment deliberately take that sword of out of the hands of the untrustworthy southern state governments and beat it into an individual right shield which applied to all citizens in all states-thereby providing the black man a means of defense against state sponsored oppression? 
 
 In other words, assuming Bogus was correct, isn't his theory rendered moot by the 14th. Amendment?
